article.headline: Utah State 57, Cal Poly 43
article.story: LOGAN, Utah (AP) -- Utah State got a very brief scare in its first game as a ranked team in 33 years. The 24th-ranked Aggies were trailing Cal Poly San Luis Obispo by a point with about 11:30 to play when they tightened up on defense. The result was a 17-2 run to close a 57-43 win Thursday night. "It just clicked. I think everybody realized that we were down by one, but I don't think anything needed to be said," said Mark Brown, who led the Aggies with 14 points. "We knew we were going to have to play defense in order to win." Spencer Nelson had 10 points and 13 rebounds, and Nate Harris scored 13 points in Utah State's 15th straight victory. The Aggies, ranked in the AP poll for the first time since March 1971, held the Mustangs to two points in the final 11:27. Utah State (18-1, 10-0 Big West) is four wins from matching the school record of 19 in a row set in 1999-00. The Mustangs (8-10, 3-7) were averaging 72.4 points coming in, but were nearly shut out for the final 10 minutes after rallying from an 11-point deficit to take a brief lead. Cal Poly scored just 19 points in the second half, going 8-for-26 from the floor. "They extended and went to their 2-3 zone and it rattled us. That's why they're a Top 25 team in the country," said Shane Schilling, who scored 17 to lead Cal Poly. Varnie Dennis added 13 points and five rebounds for the Mustangs, who attempted just six free throws in the second half, making four. Utah State struggled at the free throw line, making just 12 of 21 shots, but dominated the boards with a 40-21 rebounding advantage. Harris and Jason Williams each had seven rebounds for the Aggies. "That's just what we needed to do. They were on a run, and in order to stop that we had to get some key rebounds and some key stops to win that game," Harris said. The Aggies' winning streak never appeared to be in much danger, but they did get a scare. After Utah State went up by 11 early in the second half with its biggest lead at 37-26, Cal Poly responded with a 15-3 run. Schilling had a three-point play, a 3-pointer and completed the run on two free throws with 11:27 remaining to give Cal Poly its first lead, 41-40. However, Cal Poly went scoreless for the next 7:41, and Utah State scored the next 13 points. "We just hit a dry spell, you know? We were stuck on 41 for I don't know how long. They went to that zone and we just couldn't find the room," Schilling said. Brown started the run with a jumper just inside the 3-point line, Harris got a layup right off an inbounds pass and Brown converted a three-point play to get the Aggies rolling. After Schilling's free throws, Cal Poly didn't score again until Kameron Gray took a steal in for a layup with 3:46 to play, cutting the lead to 53-43. The Mustangs didn't score again. "Defense won the game for us once again," Brown said. "It feels great. We can't forget what got us to where we're at right now. Enjoy being ranked and all that good stuff, but just keep working hard." Cal Poly stayed close in the first half. Schilling got the Mustangs to 27-24 and could have cut the margin to two, but he missed a free throw after getting fouled while making a layup with 1:12 left in the half. Nelson added a free throw for Utah State, then took a fullcourt pass from Harris in for a two-handed dunk just before the buzzer to put the Aggies up 30-24 at halftime.
